items.title: ROOT_URLCONF not taken into account
items.body:
If you set the ROOT_URLCONF in settings.py it is not considered by django-js-reverse using the command _python manage.py collectstatic_js_reverse._ 
I would suggest the following change in collectstatic_js_reverse.py to solve this. Replace line 40:
``` 
       default_urlresolver = get_resolver(urlconf)
```
by:
```
        try:
            urlconf = settings.ROOT_URLCONF
        except AttributeError:
            urlconf = None
        default_urlresolver = get_resolver(urlconf)

```

items.title: functools and lru_cache
items.body:
We've been using this lib for a number of years - and its been fantastic.
I went to spin up a new instance of our project (which does use an old version of django - 1.7.4. in the process of upgrading...) and I got a strange error. I find it odd because I spun a new instance barely a month or so ago (maybe a bit longer..hard to be sure).
The error (below) is complaining about lru_cache, which looks as though it has been removed or something? I dont know if this is something to do with django - again I can't see why?
Any pointers, would be greatly appreciated.
Cheers

error output:
`
{  
 "cmd":"/usr/bin/pip install -U django-js-reverse",
 "failed":true,

items.title: Django 2
items.body:
[last release, remove urlsresolvers](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.0/releases/2.0/#features-removed-in-2-0) and replace by `from django.urls import resolvers` but won't keep
those functions `get_script_prefix`, `set_script_prefix`, and this release won't support python 2 at all.

items.title: Script path not taken into account
items.body:
Hi,

First of all, thanks for this library, it's a life-saver. I've come across the following issue however.

When in my Django settings, I set e.g.  FORCE_SCRIPT_NAME = "/staging"
then a template tag like {% url 'detail' 1 %} will give me an URL with "staging" prepended. Output is eg /staging/item/1.

But with django-js-reverse, it seems the setting is not taken into account. Urls.detail(1) will give me /item/1. I have set JS_REVERSE_SCRIPT_PREFIX = "/staging" too, but to no avail.

items.title: Django 1.11 support
items.body: Does anyone know if the plugin works with Django 1.11? Any idea if will be supported?

items.title: PyPI Packaging
items.body:
Hello!

The library currently installs the `tests` folder along with the `django_js_reverse` package when installing from PyPI with `pip`. The `tests` folder is installed as a separate folder as well which is a bit awkward as it could namespace clash with a folder name `tests` inside `lib/site-packages` where `pip` installs stuff to

items.title: url kwargs
items.body:
Hi,

Are there any plans to use a js object that can be used as kwargs in the url patterns?

regards,
Richard

items.title: URL Regex patterns are ignored
items.body:
When reversing an overridden URL pattern that use a regex, the regexes are ignored and the last URL is used.  

```
urlpatterns = [
    url(r'^word/(?P<b>\w+)/?$', views.call_word, name='smart_url'),
    url(r'^number/(?P<a>\d+)/?$', views.call_number, name='smart_url'),
]
```

If I call this in Django, the regex is respected and only one URL will match:
`reverse('smart_url', args=['abc'])` results in `word/abc`
`reverse('smart_url', args=[123])` results in `number/123`

In Javascript the regex is overlooked and the last URL with a matching name and number of arguments is used:

`Urls.smart_url('abc')` results in `number/abc` 
`Urls.smart_url(123)`  results in `number/123`

items.title: Templatetag js_reverse_inline breaks on Django 1.9
items.body:
I'm using the `{% js_reverse_inline %}` template tag to put the script on a couple of pages in a project. Those pages started failing with a JavaScript SyntaxError once the project was updated from Django 1.8 to 1.9, which looks to be because of [this change in template tag escaping](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.9/releases/1.9/#simple-tag-now-wraps-tag-output-in-conditional-escape). The output of the `simple_tag` is escaped by default now and a SyntaxError is raised when the parser hits `&&`.

You can work around the error by turning autoescape off around the tag:

``` html
{% autoescape off %}
<script type="text/javascript" charset="utf-8">{% js_reverse_inline %}</script>
{% endautoescape %}
```

Looking at the release notes, the proper fix seems to be to wrap the return value of `js_reverse_inline` with `mark_safe`.

items.title: 0 converted to empty string during URL construction
items.body:
First of all, django-js-reverse is amazing! The JS files now look more readable because of it.

However, recently, a strange issue came up while passing 0 (zero) as an argument to the URL -- it got translated to an empty string. In particular, I have this URL pattern:

``` python
url(r'^plot/hop_cnt_seq_num/(?P<src_node>\d+)/(?P<src_port>\d+)/(?P<dst_node>\d+)/(?P<dst_port>\d+)/$', 'hop_count_pkt_seq_num', name='trace_hop_cnt',)
```

When I invoke 

``` js
Urls.trace_hop_cnt(src_node, src_port, dst_node, dst_port)
```

from within JS with the tuple (66, 0, 67, 0), the resulting URL becomes `/plot/hop_cnt_seq_num/66//67//`, which actually should be `/plot/hop_cnt_seq_num/66/0/67/0/`. However, when invoked with (66, 1, 67, 1), it generates the correct URL `/plot/hop_cnt_seq_num/66/1/67/1/`. So somehow zeroes are being treated otherwise.

Is there any work-around for this? All other URLs are handled fine. I can manually generate the URL (like I was doing previously) as

``` js
['/plot/hop_cnt_seq_num', src_node, src_port, dst_node, dst_port].join('/') + '/'
```

that works properly.

items.title: Add more flexible support for including/excluding urls
items.body:
Hi,

I have added some external apps to my projects, and I want to exclude their urls from django-js-reverse. But the problem is that I cannot put namespace for their urls (When I set namespace, app doesn't work).

For example I have installed `django-simple-captcha` and I have added this to my urls.py:

```
url(r'^captcha/', include('captcha.urls')),
```

I want to exclude this app's urls. But when I change this line to:

```
url(r'^captcha/', include('captcha.urls', namespace='captcha')),
```

the captcha app doesn't work.

A whitelist for urls, or an option to exclude urls base on their prefix will help to solve similar issues.

Maybe:

```
EXCLUDE_PREFIXES = ['captcha', '...', ...]
```

But I think a whitelist does the job better:

```
INCLUDE_NAMESPACES = ['app1', 'app2', ...]
INCLUDE_PREFIXES = ['abc', ...]
```

items.title: The script generated inline with the command {% js_reverse_inline %} generates and error on Chrome
items.body:
Hi,

I am using django-js-reverse to get in javascript my urls and it works great but i needed to change the importing so the file is not cached on the client side after server restart. The website supports 2 languages 'en' and 'nl'. I am trying to figure out what is the best way to import the script since i am also using django-compressor.

Now i tried to use it as template tag https://github.com/ierror/django-js-reverse#usage-as-template-tag
but in Chrome i get an error. This is logged in the console, so for each user I would get a sentry error which  would not be ideal.

```
<script type="text/javascript" charset="utf-8">
{% js_reverse_inline %}
 </script>
```

This is the error:

![chrome_error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1110074/8328460/2c0c253a-1a71-11e5-9011-44c934d6f4f8.png)

I am also trying which is the best option to include the JS case in my case? If i cache it, i need to update it at the server restart since new url might appear. I tried to use the loading as static file but since I have 2 languages it does not work for me well (also generates the urls with en-us instead of en). Do you have other suggestions? 

Thanks,
Vlad

items.title: Mapping under suburl doesn't work
items.body:
I have a page running under a suburl like example.org/foo/

When running manage.py collectstatic_js_reverse, it does not take this into account.

items.title: Namespace param to include breaks URLs output by jsreverse
items.body:
Imagine I have a base `urls.py`:

``` python
urlpatterns = patterns(
    '',

    url(r'^(?P<project_slug>[a-z0-9-_]{1,256})/signup/',
        include('myapp.signup.urls',
                namespace='signup',
                app_name='signup'),),
)
```

The URLs inside of `myapp.signup.urls` are defined as:

``` python
urlpatterns = patterns(
    '',

    url(r'^create/?$',
        view=SignupConfigCreateView.as_view(),
        name='create'),
)
```

The result (relevant part only) of the JS is:

```
url_patterns = [
                [
                    'signup:create', ['(?P<project_slug>[a-z0-9-_]{1,256})/signup/create', []]
                ],
        ];
```

This is not correct. 

If I leave out the namespace param in the include call as such:

``` python
urlpatterns = patterns(
    '',

    url(r'^(?P<project_slug>[a-z0-9-_]{1,256})/signup/',
        include('myapp.signup.urls',
                app_name='signup'),),
)
```

the result JS is correct:

```
url_patterns = [
                [
                    'create', ['%(project_slug)s/signup/create', ['project_slug']]
                ]
        ];
```

items.title: Limit the exposed URLs using a white/blacklist
items.body:
It would be great if one was able to limit the URLs exposed in this view to avoid giving away too much information about the URLs available on the site, so only the necessary ones (actually used by Javascript) are shown.

I think it would be impossible to automatically deduce which ones are used by the site's Javascript files, but maybe it would be possible to choose which ones to expose in the urlconfig file.

Any suggestions for the best way to handle this? I'll happily make a patch but not sure about the exact approach.

items.title: Typo
items.body:
"Django JS Reverse is a small django app that makes url handling of named urls in javascript easy and none annoying."
should read:

"Django JS Reverse is a small django app that makes url handling of named urls in javascript easy and non-annoying."

items.title: Please update PyPI
items.body: Can you please upload the newest version on PyPI?

items.title: Support URL namespaces
items.body:
Currently namespaced URLs do not work. Example urls.py:

```
url(r'^myApp/', include('myApp.urls', namespace='myApp')),
```

No URL of 'myApp' will show up because urlresolvers.get_resolver(None) seems to only return non-namespaced URLs.

Also, the current javascript Urls (function-)object wouldn't like that because of the colons in the name, Urls.myApp:myUrl is not a valid javascript variable. A separate function would be necessary, something like:

```
Urls.get('myApp:betterliving_get_house', 'house', 12)
```

Any other idea on how to solve that?

items.title: URL returned with out prefix
items.body:
My django project is bind on /my_project/
And I have a url pattern r("^to_do", to_do, name=to_do)
When I use Urls.to_do(), it returns "/to_do" not "/my_project/to_do"
